Situation1: Their partner had a mildly stressful day at work and mentions it casually.
Situation2: A winter storm is slowing traffic while the passenger must catch an international flight
Story: I glance at my phone as I wait at a red light, snow swirling outside the windshield. My husband’s text pops up: “Rough day. Just want to talk when you get home.” I can almost hear the tiredness in his words, and I know he needs me to listen, to be present, to offer comfort. But right now, my focus is split. In the back seat, my passenger checks his watch for the third time, anxiety etched on his face. “I really can’t miss this flight,” he says, voice tight. The roads are slick, traffic crawling, and every minute feels like an hour. I want to reassure him, to drive faster, but safety comes first. My mind races—how can I be the supportive wife my husband needs tonight, when I’m already stretched thin trying to get this man to the airport on time and in one piece? The weight of both expectations presses on me, and I grip the steering wheel, heart pounding, torn between the two worlds that need me right now.
